content: After the murder of eleven Jewish's athletes during 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Israeli government decides to build a secret vengeance against the murderers. For that, a secret commando composed of five men was placed under the order of a young leader, Aver. Their mission was to search and kill each member of the Palestinian commando who has participate to hostage seizure, wherever they were in the world. During several years, the Jewish commando kills nine among Palestinian terrorists. But several members of Israeli's commando will be killed. It is a magnificent movie full of humanity. Steven Spielberg shows the diverse reactions of the commando members, especially Avner's one and insists on the vanity of violence to solve conflicts between human communities.

title: Spielberg Back On Track
content: After the disappointment of War of The Worlds, let down by some hammy acting and a weak storyline, Munich goes a long way towards restoring Spielberg's reputation. Based on Mossad's response to the siege and killing of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics, this is a near flawless piece.The storyline is excellent, relying heavily on family/nation imagery throughout, from when Avner meets Golda Meir, the Israeli Prime Minister who remembers his father and comments on his wife's pregnancy, to Avner being disenfranchised from Mossad and missing out on the upbringing of his daughter.The acting performances bring together some quality actors, such as Ciaran Hinds, Daniel Craig, the legendary Michel Lonsdale and the ever consistent Geoffrey Rush. Although he does not have the same reputation, Eric Bana's performance as an assassin and family man is excellent. Ruthless in his duty, his softer side comes to the fore when he hears his daughter's first words over the phone, arguably the most heart wrenching scene in the film.But what is most impressive is the attention to detail to what is a period piece. The mixture of original ABC archive footage with reconstruction of the siege is eerily accurate. The scenes of all of the locations is truly a step back to the 70s, even down to the inclusion of the World Trade Centre in New York.At 2 and a half hours, this one long film. But the drama is so unrelenting that the time whizzes by. And for such a violent film, the futility of violence is given considerable emphasis. Spielberg can take pride in this piece of work. He'll now have a hell of a job on his hands to follow this up. But if Munich wins the Best Picture Oscar, will he care?

title: Where can I get that leather backpack?
content: I saw Munich last week and I thought it was great! Eric Bana is so handsome and his wife in the movie was very pretty too. They had very good chemistry together.Does anyone know where I can find the brown leather backpack that Eric Bana (Avner) uses when he takes money out of the bank? I've looked high and low but without knowing who makes it, etc. I'm not having much luck finding one.My husband would absolutely love to have one like it ... he loves men's bags, clutches and backpacks. I'd love to surprise him with it on his birthday in October. Please send me an e-mail if you know where I can get one. Thank You!Julie JulesMk69@aol.com

title: What can I say.... few movies bring tears to my eyes
content: A strong movie with quite a lot of questions asked but not always answered. A movie with over all strong performance by superb but not always "star" actors. Does violence breed violence?? What is wonderful about this movie is that the actors never rule the story. All actors are subdued by a story, very strong and believe it or not very non partial. I've never in my life felt 164 minutes pass with such ease. Spielberg really sticks his neck out on this one but on the other hand he raises a lot of questions that applies on 1972 as well as today. Violence always breeds violence! Doesn't it? In any way this movie in my mind clearly competes with other movies nominated this year. None of them... in my mind are as important as "Munich" a year as this...

title: No Side
content: This is a Great movie, I'm not either denomination, just enjoyed the suspense, the acting, the history makes me go read about it every time I watch it. Each person or group has its own reasons for participating in these events whether it's vengeance, country, religion, or soul, in the end it's the same "human nature" and the ugliness that engulfs all beings. Money is always the thing that keeps this stuff alive in the end. As far as movies go this was great cinema.

title: Spielberg does it again
content: Steven Spielberg is the King Midas of the movie world. Everything he does is spectacular and even with the films that you may not like (i.e. war of the worlds) there is absolutely no denying the brilliance each film holds.Munich is no exception to this. The casting was perhaps one of the highlights, as it was almost (though surely unintentionally) reminiscent of a crew from the original series of Mission:Impossible. At this point, allow me to say that by making that point i am not suggesting Munich is tacky or a popcorn film, (besides, the original series of Mission:Impossible will remain a classic), i am simply hinting that it was understandable why the film didn't win a Globe.However, the film addresses some issues that some people may get the wrong idea of. Most prominent is the Israeli issue. I have read a fair number of reviews and certainly spoken to a fair few people that feel Munich is almost appraising of the terrorist actions. This is not the case. What the film does is highlight the appraisal the terrorists gave their own actions and how they did it (on TV) and how they seemed self-contained and perhaps 'untouchable' from any official prosecution.This is where Avner Kaufman and his team come in. They are recruited to execute those responsible for the terrorist actions. This is the 'meat' of the story which touches new territory for Spielberg and like i said, he does not disappoint...

title: My Munichcipalaties have decided that this film deserves a Silver medal!
content: Steven Spieldberg has been praised as the premier "gold medal" director in cinematic history. There are many that share that sentiment while others that opinion that he is more in the "silver or bronze" auteur medal category. Why I am I getting into such a "medalica" state in describing Spieldberg's career? Because his latest controversial flick is inspired by true events of a historic horrific Olympic tragedy. Many know it as Black September. It was during the 1972 Summer Olympics held in Munich when 11 Israeli athletes & coaches were assassinated by a Palestinian terrorist group. The premise of "Munich" is what happened next. Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir ordered a vengeance strike against the Palestinians planners of Black September. The Israeli covert revenge team was led by a former security officer turned agent named Avner. His subordinates were comprised of a former toymaker now bomb crafter, a forgery specialist, a practical agent, and an experienced schematic hit specialist. These Mossad agents are not exactly the Israeli armed forces "high five" but remember the operation was very clandestine one. The main focal point is that they seek revenge for Munich, non-stop. It is no bullocks that the film has sparked up controversy from Palestinian and even Israeli groups. Palestinians state that Spieldberg depicts them as unmerciful terrorists while Israelis state that he was too lenient against the non-pals Palestis. Personally, I thought Spieldberg was too harsh against his own Israelis, "jew" know what I mean. Hey, if this film is controversial why can't this review be of the same caliber? The film's "message for peace" signifies that revenge is useless and non-resolving by having Israeli apply egoistic vengeful tactics. Eric Bana executed a Herculean performance as Avner. Bana masterfully portrayed Avner as a righteous family man, a devoted countryman, and later a conflicted hit-man. Spieldberg's recreation of the Munich horror integrated with actual footage was resourceful and effective. The screenplay of "Munich" was complex, but yet, suspenseful. Writers Tony Kushner and Eric Roth did give "Munich" justice by giving Spieldberg their "words". Undoubtedly, Spieldberg has developed a cerebral film. "Munich" is not a masterpiece, but it is startling enough for one never to forget that striking back is the same as striking out. Games Over! **** Good

title: Not your usual action movie!
content: Munich is a movie that exposes the effects of the prevailing principles of "peace" on the men at the receiving end. It is an intelligent movie that does not stress and excruciate the viewer despite its long running time.One thing is for certain-- the cinematography is very intelligent. It seemed as if the camera angles alone would tell a story! The cinematography also gives the movie that sort of suspenseful air that makes the movie rather slow than the usual fast-paced.Another factor that makes Munich watchable till the end is the story development. The ending was definitely an ending, unfolding a hidden plot that has been running throughout the film. It does not rely on the killing of the targets to keep the story going.Munich definitely has a plot, and it keeps that plot running until the end. The actors all gave good performances, and the cinematography aids the overall mood the movie wishes to impart to the viewers.Final say? Definitely not your usual action movie! It's sleek and intelligent, and it definitely has a plot unlike other action movies which depend on the action sequences to keep audience members watching!

title: Emperor Spielberg is NAKED
content: "Munich" is overrated by most reviewers. I am here to report that emperor Spielberg is naked! The script is bad almost throughout the movie. The directing is sloppy almost throughout the movie. The first part of the movie looks like a low budget movie. Several scenes don't make any sense (the meeting of Israelis and Palestinians in the same room; the final sex scene of the main character with his wife). The scenes that did get more attention are the violent scenes. I find a contradiction between the main message of the movie that violence does not pay and between the extra care in directing the violent scenes because... violence does pay.

title: Shocking, Violent, Involved
content: There is a definite message in this film and it's obvious to anyone who sees this movie and understands politics. It's important to point out that this film is "based on real events" and is not true-to-life as far as the history of Munich's aftermath. If you're okay with that, then it's an excellent story.If you are planning to see an action flick, this is probably not for you. This film is emotional, complex and the characters spend a lot more time talking then they do killing. When the sequences of "killing" do occur, it is nothing short of shocking.The acting is tremendous to say the least, and if you're thinking about seeing it, might I recommend a large screen and loud speakers for those sporadic sequences of action. They are very loud and very intense.Spielberg shows his directorial expertise by using a type of film enhancement that makes it appear like "Munich" was shot in the 1970's, but at the same time couples it with the modern visual/special effects technology which makes some of the more violent scenes seem like we're on location with the actual assassins doing their dirty work.As far as sex goes, there are a couple of mild scenes between the main character and his wife, of which the latter scene could've been omitted because of its bizarre connotation. Secondly, there is a scene where a woman appears in full-frontal nudity, but I will warn you it's not a sex scene.I would have given this film a "10" except that there were some scenes that slowed the movie down and also the fact that I would have rather seen a more true-to-history depiction of "Munich".

title: A tale of moral complexity appropriate in our complex times.
content: A lot of people are angry about the film Munich because it is too sympathetic to those they would prefer to hate. This willingness to see humanity in the face of 'the enemy' is precisely why this film is so very important. If everyone could see the humanity of those they hate, how much less violence might there be in the world? Many resist morally complex thinking. It is much easier to see the world in terms of good versus evil. Thinking in absolutes removes unsettling doubts about our place in the world. The problem is, everyone has a point of view, and when pushed to the limit of human experience, people can justify almost anything.In such difficult times as these, when we all feel threatened and angry at those who engage in senseless violence, it is important to remember how easy it can be to descend into our most savage nature when we feel threatened. Every character in Munich is allowed to have his moment of doubt, even of horror, at the violence he or she commits. Even characters on "the other side" are shown having their doubts before pulling the trigger. Munich asks the question: Should we let the murderers make us into murderers? If we do, what in the end are we defending, and what will be the end of it? Munich wisely refrains from answering this question, perhaps because we are all still waiting to learn the answer.

title: Extraordinary!
content: Every film made by Spielberg left a mark on me for good. That guy simply has all the talent and information and resources to make a good film. This film is no exception. Many things are said about Steven, but I just want to add this. He simply had all the best in him to make it to the top, not only in the movie making but in the American and civilized world. He is respected by many people, and rightfully so. Too bad we do not have more people like him in the world. World would of been a better place. However, I am not sure that is possible given state of the affairs in the world today. It is probably going to get worse, and I am afraid that a civilized part of the world is going to get more uncivilized. Unfortunately!As far as this film goes, everything was fantastic, from the beginning to the end, plot, acting, sets. The scene which will stick in my, and probably in everyone else*s mind is the scene of the murder of the naked Dutch woman.

title: An emotional, character based drama
content: Steven Spielberg has done it again. He is one of the best Sci-Fi directors of all time but he also shines in Non-fiction dramas as well. Personally I think this is much better than Lincoln, but not nearly as good as Saving Private Ryan. It dives deep into how Avner had to deal with the psychological troubles assassins go through. Eric Bana plays the lead and gives the character much depth that I think the other characters struggled from. May very well be Bana's best performance in his career. Daniel Craig was also good as one of his four partners, (Pre James Bond days). What I really liked about this film was the fact that they didn't cut out the Israeli's as the heroes. As dark of a film as it is, it needed lighter and more pleasant scenes, and you get that with Bana's family, lead by the beautiful Ayelet Zurer. It's truly a great historical piece, no matter how close it was to depicting true events or not. John Williams also added intensity with his score, and the cinematography was great as well. I can't really say it was an enjoyable film, considering people were being killed every 15 minutes, but its an interesting watch. Especially if your not familiar with the terrors that occurred in Munich. 8.3/10

title: Zzzzz... wake me up when it's finished
content: This has to be the most boring movie I've ever seen. My wife and I weren't even able to watch it straight thru. We had to split it in two sessions of torture. Gawd... Not much action... to much foreign dialog, some translated, some not. That movie is DARK. I mean, almost 90% of the movie takes place on a cloudy day or at night. It's also too long... They could have made this in 1 hour and I still doubt it would be interesting. The whole structure of the movie should be changed. Some narration would have been a good idea IMHO.Anyway, that movie should be sold in drugstores, in the sleeping pills isle.Sponge

title: This is a great movie about the emotions involved in the aftermath of the attacks, but lacks historical facts
content: This movie is done in the vein of the countless other historical epics that Spielberg has directed, and will move anyone who sees it. While it is based on true life events, it appears as though it is mainly directed toward connecting the events in the film to our modern day struggle with terrorism, rather than simply stating the facts. Largely unknown to most of the "Munich" audience, another movie was made for TV based on the same novel by George Jonas almost exactly twenty years ago called, "The Sword of Gideon." I watched this movie about two years ago, and while it doesn't convey as much emotion as "Munich" (i.e. lower budget and non-inventive camera work), it does cover a larger time-line with many more facts. There tends to be definite political statement made in "Munich", and therefore I would recommend seeing both movies to get the big picture. If at all possible, watch the "Sword of Gideon" first to get a more historical background, and then watch "Munich". If you just watched "Munich", and are wondering what happened to Avner beyond where the movie leaves off, watch "Sword of Gideon".

title: Spielberg delivers yet another masterpiece!
content: This film is truly, hands down, the greatest film of 2005. If it does not get nominated for best picture, best Director (Spielberg) and best actor (Eric Bana), I will be sorely disappointed.I will not mention the plot in this review, because most people have a loose idea already, and if not, those people who haven't should really see it regardless of the story.This film is one of the most profound, deep, emotionally compelling films of the decade. It haunted me for the rest of the afternoon after I left the theater and it is still leaving a huge impression on me.Eric Bana's heavily emotional Israeli drives the movie, but of course there is excellent help from the supporting cast with the likes of Daniel Craig and Geoffrey Rush. It is beautifully shot: the action scenes will have your heart racing in each one, guaranteed.John Williams also delivers again, creating a haunting, memorable score that is just one of the many ingredients that makes this a classic.In conclusion, though this film can be quite violent and y at times, it is a must see for those are old enough to see it. I am an 18 year old high school senior, and this film changed my life. I would suggest for everyone, no matter what your beliefs. In my opinion, Munich should be the film to take Best Picture this year.

title: Hard hitting politics and emotionally distraught souls
content: Hard hitting, from all points of view...A difficult story wrought with the troubled past of two nations.. Spielberg has successfully brought about a film which explores a seemingly endless conflict where there are no winners.It provides us with a political and personal overview of the darker elements of the men, women, families and children that directly endure the brutality and hostility of a fruitless heritage of unexplainable and impossible hatred...Although the film uses the events of the Munich Olympic killings as it's theme I believe that it explores a much larger panoply of social,political and worldly behaviours... It is a reminder that we as a species are not quite ready to evolve...

title: When the sports world changed
content: The Summer Olympic Games were underway in the first week of September 1972. The Olympic Games were generally a joyous time of sportsmanship and competition. However, in this Olympics the world was changed when terrorists from the Black September group managed to infiltrate the Olympic village. They took 9 members of the Israeli Olympic team hostage and killed two others in the process. The terrorists demanded the release of over two hundred of their jailed comrades and flight out of what was then Munich, West Germany. The German officials attempted a rescue of the hostages, but the result was that all nine hostages were killed. Three of the terrorists survived.As a consequence of this event, the Israeli government authorized what they referred to as Operation Wrath of God. The security forces were told to hunt down and kill all people involved in planning the attack. This movie is a rendition of the actions of the Israeli team of agents that engaged in the killings.This is a tense movie and to the extent that it is possible, shows the events in a reasonable approximation to what actually happened. There were five members of the Israeli team from disparate backgrounds. The events of the taking of the hostages up to when they were killed is shown in flashback snippets, with the allegation that West German authorities bungled the rescue attempt not appearing until very late in the movie.The very brutal world of tit-for-tat terrorist acts between the Israelis and the Palestinians in the seventies is very much a part of the plot. Some of the violence is very graphic, but the turmoil felt by the agents is also an integral part of the story. Most of the people they kill are very respectable looking, totally outside the mold of the wild-eyed pistol waver. As they take care of their targets, there is a great deal of concern expressed by the team members as to whether they are really making a difference, wondering whether they were simply escalating the terrorist violence.This is a great movie, worthy of the accolades it received. However, if you do not understand the basic history of the event, reaching the proper level of historical significance of the events may not be possible.

title: Disappointed
content: What disappointed me the most was that the director mishandled the subject and made it into an action/thriller film rather than a thought-provoking drama. Terrence Malick would have been a wonderful choice. Throughout the whole film, I kept wondering if I were watching Munich or Mission: Impossible and Godfather flicks.I also had problems with Mr. Spielberg's portraying of violence on the screen. Obviously, he didn't believe the philosophy of "less is more" as he depicted the killings full on. Most of the adult audience gasped whenever a violent deed was committed on the screen. I didn't think that thoughts rather than fears were provoked as we were wondering when, where and how the next one was going to hit the screen.The film score also presented a problem to me. It reminded me so much of Schindler's List. I guess that Mr. William ran out of ideas and simply recycle his old scores.The climax at the end (intercutting of a "domestic event" and the Munich tragedy) was really uncalled for and tasteless. It was disrespectful to draw such parallel.However, I find Mr. Spielberg was courageous setting the tone of the film, neither Pro- Israel nor Anti-Palestine. The question of "does retribution or an-eye-for-an-eye policy toward peace really work" was constantly brought up through out the film. 30 years after the Munich tragedy, we all know the result (albeit it's a sad truth).I only wish Mr. Spielberg made this film the way Terrence Malick made The Thin Red Line: subtle, philosophical yet thought-provoking.

title: one of the most powerful and thought provoking films you will ever see
content: quite simply, this movie is one of the most thought provoking, disturbing and utterly human portrayal of real life that your ever going to get.as a 19 year old, i went into it not fully understanding the subject matter, came out not really understanding all the details, but the main thing i got from this film, which was driven into my mind through the mesmirising acting of a superb cast, is that in war there is never one side to a story, no side is ever completely innocent.i cannot possibly explain the impact this movie has. the realistic and gritty filming makes it seem almost as if your walking along with the characters. one of the group. you feel their emotion, and piece together information as they get it.no comment is ever going to do this film justice. YOU HAVE TO SEE IT, you will remember it. this film is truly a masterpiece, and will be remembered for years to come. though the situation was based on real events, the emotions, and the concepts are easily applied to modern day.what most upset me, was that 30 years on, and we are still making the same mistakes.just because somebody is on the opposite side, does not make them the enemy.i fight you because u fight me. you fight me because i fight you.its horrific. this film is a must see.

title: Good,Good
content: Munich is a great film.In two hours and thirty minutes,you have a state of thrilling constant.It is not bored in any moment. Interpretations are correct.The final is the part of movie that i didn't like very much. In the technical capitol, photography and mounting are brilliant. Although, i don't have lived in those years, i think that the movie is set very well in that period.Spielberg has worked how he's in the habit. Munich is better than Saving Private Ryan's,however this isn't than spectacular. Munich will join in the selected group of mythical movies and normally, must be a favorite movie in the all international movie trophies of this year(Oscar,Golden Globe,Venecia,Cannes,Valladolid,Sitges,San Sebastian and more).completely recommendable.

title: Polished and nuanced film, which poses tough questions.
content: Political extremists don't like this film because, well, this film attempts to provide a nuanced view on terrorism, and violence. This is a film that is about characters and their psychological makeup, and how they respond to the missions they are asked to accomplish and what happens to them as they move closer towards their goal. The acting is superb, the characters are real, the dialogue is sharp and intelligent, and visually the film is stunning to look at (I watched it in high def, wow).The attention to detail with 70's era cars, clothes and hairstyles was also excellent.This movie is about assassinations, and it does get bloody (graphically bloody), so it isn't for the squeamish, but its a thoroughly enjoyable movie, even if it is a bit long at 2:40, nothing in the film seems rushed or thrown in. I'd give it an 8.5 out of 10, and its definitely something i'd like to have in my collection.

title: The A teem on a really bad day!
content: This film is so annoying to me as an Israeli, has this Spielberg dude even been to Israel? I think the answer is NO, this film is total distortion of facts, its based on a distorted book. The film "Sword of Gideon" is also based on the book "vengeance" but is much better because it is not so ambiguous.Lets make something very clear here: the terrorist group that murdered the Israeli athletes are not spokesmen of Palestinian people! Did not "fight" for Palestinian people, Not all Palestinian people are terrorists but this stupid film makes it so.This film makes the mossad look like the A teem on a really bad day, and also makes the whole ANTI TERROR actions seem like a silly vengeance of Israel, I can assure you that without anti terror actions terrorists would have an even bigger filed trip then they already do.its stupid and irresponsible to say that doing NOTHING about terrorism is the answer to peace. On the contrary alertness and agreement to fight back when stuck down IS the answer to freedom.Don't forget BLACK September are nothing more then terrorists! Look up the word terrorist in the dictionary!About the film itself: quite boring and long, the "countries" are not really, France, Holland, UK and Israel but really Malta, this sucks because it makes the film look like 1960's "mission impossible"PLUS PIONT OF FILM IS - BANA YUMMY Eric Bana, that's is a very hot gorgeous man and actor,the film was a waist of time money and made me really angry.

title: brilliant
content: A dark harrowing film, that does not patronise the viewer like fellow best picture nominee Crash. The ambivalence of the films morals only heightens the cinema going experience challenging the viewer with its unclear message. I, personally had no issues with the films apparent lack of historical accuracy, but if thats your priority when you pay to be entertained then maybe you'll have trouble with this film. This is undoubtedly Spielbergs best film of the last decade and I truly believe that in time I will be rating it as one his best, if not his best ever. The lighting is superb, like the best of noir but it serves not to show a man constrained by a femme fa tale but rather the fright of becoming one of the cold blooded killers that the terrorist retaliation squad so hate. I would wright more but i haven't got the time at the moment but I cant recommend this film highly enough it truly is a modern great.
